newsitem.title: FRANCE: U.S., Europeans meet on Zaire in Paris.
newsitem.headline: U.S., Europeans meet on Zaire in Paris.

text.p: Senior officials from the United States and six European nations on Tuesday urged withdrawal of all foreign forces from Zaire and respect for existing borders as part of efforts to end warring in Central Africa.

Foreign ministry experts from Germany, France, Britain, Spain, Belgium the Netherlands -- current president of the European Union -- and the United States met in Paris for informal talks on ways to resolve the crisis in Zaire.

"The participants underlined the urgency for an end to hostilities and for the withdrawal of all outside forces," a French Foreign Ministry statement said after the talks, also attended by the EU envoy to the Great Lakes region, Aldo Ajello.

"They call on all the parties to ensure the safety of refugees and displaced people," it said, adding that the officials reaffirmed support for "the territorial integrity of Zaire and of all other states in the region".

The officials said the crisis should be resolved by "talks, implementation of the electoral process and the calling of the international conference, under the auspices of the United Nations and the Organisation of African Unity, for peace, security and development in the region of the Great Lakes."
The officials, meeting as part of a French initiative, agreed to give support and to work closely with U.N. special envoy Mohammed Sahnoun, a veteran Algerian diplomat.

Zaire announced new bombing raids on rebel-held towns in the east of the country on Tuesday, a change in tack in a faltering government counter-offensive launched on January 20 to retake territory from rebels who took up arms in October.

Foreign mercenaries, notably Serbs, are fighting the rebels alongside Zaire's indisciplined army. Zaire accuses neighbouring Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda of fighting alongside the rebels. All three deny the charge.
